title.narrative: EQUAL RIGHTS AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR WOMEN AND GIRLS PROJECT - EROP PROJECT

description.narrative: Objective 1• To contribute towards the elimination of SGBV in target communities in selected Districts by the end of September 2021 Objective 2• To promote women and girls’ economic empowerment through livelihood and entrepreneurial skills development by the end of September 2021 in the EROP Project Districts. To increase the capacities of Social Justice Institutions for enhanced delivery of services to women and girls by the end of September 2021 in the EROP Project Districts. Objective 3• To contribute to an improved environment for women’s and girls’ participation in decision making by the end of September 2021 in Ghana.

The Equal Rights and Opportunities for Women and Girls Project dubbed the EROP Project is being implemented as a response to numerous human rights challenges women and girls in particular continue to face and as a result do not realize their rights and take opportunities for the advancement of their ambitions and to live fulfilled lives. This project seeks to ensure that women and girls in Ghana realize their human rights and utilize opportunities that enable them to live successful lives. To achieve this goal, the project educate women and girls on their human rights and those of others and opportunities available to them as part of efforts to empower them to hold duty bearers accountable; train women and girls on entrepreneurial skills and opportunities for economic empowerment; strengthen the capacity of Social Justice Institutions for prevention of violence and timely and successful intervention when violence occurs; advocate for the passage of the Affirmative Action Bill which has been pending for more than two decades and increase support for women and girls in Communities and Schools on their human rights so that violations are addressed and respect for everyone’s rights is sustained. The EROP Project is being funded tby Dutch Embassy in Ghana and implemented by Members of the Ghana SRHR Alliance (GH Alliance), Africa Centre for Human Rights and Sustainable Development (AfCHuRSD) and WOMEN IN NEED (WIN).
The Goal of the project is to contribute to the realization of gender equality and opportunities for women and girls to live successful lives in Ghana by the end of September 2021.

participating-org.narrative: Africa Centre for Human Rights and Sustainable Development
Ghana SRHR Alliance for Young People

activity-date.narrative: Implementation of all activities is to end on the 30th of September 2021
The project was launched at the national level on the 19th of November 2020

title.narrative: 1.1 Increased knowledge of women, girls, men and boys on the human rights of women and girls and opportunities available to them in target districts by the end of September 2021.

description.narrative: % of women, girls, men and boys in target districts with knowledge on gender equality/equity, SGBV and Discrimination against women and girls who report cases of violence to Social Justice Institutions for redress

title.narrative: % increase in number of women, girls, men and boys in target districts with knowledge on gender equality/equity, SGBV and Discrimination against women and girls who report cases of violence to Social Justice Institutions for redress

description.narrative: The performance of this indicator was low due to the fact that although the knowledge of the community members increased , they were a bit hesitant coming forward to report cases of violence to Social Justice Institution for redress. At baseline , the project recorded 39.4% and at endline 40 % was recorded

comment.narrative: this indicator one is measured by the percentage increase in knowledge of women, girls, men and boys on the human rights of women and girls and opportunities available to them in target districts by the end of September 2021. by 50 %

title.narrative: 3.1.1.Conduct an initial meeting to activate the network of CSOs for Joint Advocacy on the passage of the Affirmative Action Bill in Parliament, enforcement of Maternity Leave for women and initiation of discussions on paternity leave policy

description.narrative: A meeting is conducted with other CSO working towards the passage of the Affirmative Action Bill in Parliament, enforcement of Maternity Leave for women and initiation of discussions on paternity leave policy to form Lobby committees to engage policy makers

title.narrative: # and type of Lobby Committees formed as a strategy to influence key actor to pass the Affirmative Action Bill, review and improve maternity leave policy for women and paternity leave policy for men

description.narrative: The project joined the Coalition for the passage Affirmative Action Bill to form a lobby committee to lobby with the common focus of getting the bill passed alongside the consideration of improve maternity leave policy for women and paternity leave policy for men

title.narrative: # of engagement of lobby committees to influence key actor to pass the Affirmative Action Bill, review and improve maternity leave policy for women and paternity leave policy for men

description.narrative: Number of engagement of lobby committees to influence key actor to pass the Affirmative Action Bill, review and improve maternity leave policy for women and paternity leave policy for men

title.narrative: 3. Socio-cultural, political and legal environment improved for women and girls’ participation in decision-making in their environments.

description.narrative:
An enabling environment created where women can participate in decision making in their environment. This outcome focused on the passing of the Affirmative Action Bill in Ghana, through advocacy... The Project had 5 milestones to measure the success of their advocacy.
Milestones 1. Join the AAB Coalition 2. Have a face to face meeting with the Ministry of Gender , Children and Social Protection 3. Training of 25 Journalists to support the advocacy on the AAB through the local , mass and social media 4.Have a lobby meeting with influential members of parliament to solicit their support 5. Have the AAB read and discussed in parliament and passed

title.narrative: # of key milestones realized towards passage of the Affirmative Action Bill, towards improved maternity leave arrangement for womenabd initiating discussion on paternity leave policy

description.narrative:
Number of key milestones realized towards passage of the Affirmative Action Bill, towards improved maternity leave arrangement for women and initiating discussion on paternity leave policy
This outcome focused on the passing of the Affirmative Action Bill in Ghana, through advocacy... The Project had 5 milestones to measure the success of their advocacy.
Milestones 1. Join the AAB Coalition 2. Have a face to face meeting with the Ministry of Gender , Children and Social Protection 3. Training of 25 Journalists to support the advocacy on the AAB through the local , mass and social media 4.Have a lobby meeting with influential members of parliament to solicit their support 5. Have the AAB read and discussed in parliament and passed
Achieved milestones 1.Join the AAB Coalition 2. Members of the AA Bill Coalition and the EROP Project Management Committee met with the Deputy Minister of Gender, Children and Social Protection to hold key discussions on how the AA Bill could be passed 3.Training of 25 Journalists to support the advocacy on the AAB through the local , mass and social media 4. Have a lobby meeting with influential members of parliament to solicit their support

title.narrative: 1. Enabling environment for the elimination of Violence against women improved

description.narrative: Increased awareness on SGBV and readiness to act in response to occurrence of SGBV in communities by community stakeholders

title.narrative: % increase in the awareness and readiness of community stakeholders to recognize and act/respond positively on cases of SGBV

description.narrative:
Increased awareness on SGBV and readiness to act in response to occurrence of SGBV in communities by community stakeholder
There was a 28% increase with regards to this indicator. At baseline, the project recorded 67% of community stakeholders being aware and being ready to act in response to ocurrence of SGBV. AT endline this percentage increase to 95%.

title.narrative: 1.2 Increased use and potential use of Social Justice Institutions’ services in selected districts by the end of September 2021

description.narrative: Increased number of prosecution of cases of violence as a result increase in use of social justice institution

title.narrative: % increase in the prosecution of cases of violence by Social Justice Institutions’ services (DOVVSU, CHRAJ, etc)

description.narrative:
This indicator sort to measure Increased number of prosecution of cases of violence
The project project evaluation could not have access to information on the number of prosecuted cases recorded during the baseline and endline evaluation .This was because the Social Justice Institution were not willing to give out such confidential information out with the consent of the survivor/victims involves

comment.narrative: '10% increase in number of prosecuted cases

title.narrative: % increase in the use and potential use of Social Justice Institutions’ services by community members

description.narrative: An increase in the use and potential use of the services provided by Social Justice institutions. This indicator sort to measure the change in the use and potential use of the services provided by Social Justice institutions. At baseline 20.7% of respondents stated they had used or would use the services of the Social Justice Institutions, At endline 32.7% was recorded.. This gives a percentage increase of 12%

comment.narrative: '10% increase in number of prosecuted cases

description.narrative:
MFA indicator based on 3.1.2
# and type of key Actors (Government Ministries, Departments /Agencies, Parliament, Think-Tanks, Religious Organizations, leadership of TUC, etc.) influenced by EROP Lobby Committees to act on the passage of Affirmative Action Bill, improvement of maternity leave policy for women and Paternity leave policy for men.
The project was able to engage the Deputy Minister of Gender ,Children and Social Protection The project also engaged and joined the 10 members lobbying committee of the Affirmative Action Coalition. The lobby committee was able to engage the Speaker of Parliament and 3 other influential parliamentarians to solicit for their support for the passage of the bill

title.narrative: Dutch Ministry of Finance Affairs indicator 1.1.

description.narrative: MFA indicator based on indicator 1.1.3, 1.3.3, 1.3.4 and 1.3.6

title.narrative: # of laws, policies and strategies blocked, adopted or improved to eradicate all forms of violence against women and girls in public and private life (link CSD2**)

description.narrative:
MFA indicator based on indicator 1.1.3, 1.3.1, and 1.3.4
Indicator 1.1.3 recorded 55 EROP support group formed and adopted as strategies to increase knowledge of women, girls, men and boys on gender equality/equity, SGBV and Discrimination against women and girls
Indicator 1.3.1 recorded 60 EROP School Support Clubs formed and adopted as in-school strategies
Indicator 1.3.3 recorded 33 bye-laws that are being enforced and in the process of being enacted by the district assemblies after the community leadership had agreed of them

comment.narrative: Sum of 1.1.3, 1.3.1, and 1.3.4 Calculated after all outputs are filled in.

title.narrative: Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs indicator 1.2

description.narrative: MFA indicator based on indicator 1.1.5, 1.2.2, 1.2,3 and 1.3.2 and 1.3.5

title.narrative: # of targeted actors (disaggregated by type, age and gender) with improved knowledge, attitudes and practises towards the elimination of all forms of violence, including harmful practices

description.narrative:
MFA indicator based on indicator 1.1.4, 1.1.5, 1.1.6,1.1.2, 1.2.2, 1.2,3 1.3.2 ,1.3.3, 1.3.5,1.3.6 and 1.3.7
1.1.4a # of EROP Support team members trained to educate, capture and report cases of violence to Social Justice Institutions for full prosecution of perpetrators. = 335(185 females and 150 males)
1.1.5a1 # of women/grils reached with education sessions by EROP support group = 11134 women and girls
1.1.5a2 # of men/boys reached with education sessions by EROP support group =6276 men and boys
1.1.5b # of community of members reporting cases of SGBV to EROP Support Teams or Social Justice Institutions for appropriate actions = 122 (66 females and 56 males)
1.1.6a # of men and boys who act to prevent violence and discrimination against women and girls in their communities. = 249 men and boys
1.2.1 # of national(district/regional) level social justice institutions representative attending meetings =79(36 females and 43 males)
1.2.2b # of people reporting cases of violence reported = 39(12 females and 27 males)
1.2.3 # of National, Regional and District level Social Justice officers enforcing the full persecution of SGBV cases reported = 36(11 females and 25 males)
1.3.2 # of Teachers trained to conduct step-down trainings for the EROP School Support Clubs =131(60 females and 71 males)
1.3.3 # of EROP School Support Clubs member trained to prevent SGBV in schools in target communities =537 girls
1.3.5 # of Community leaderships that commit to supporting the work of the EROP Support Teams to report cases of violence in their communities =417(163 females and 254 males)
1.3.6b # of School Heads / Teachers /Support Staff within the EROP Project Areas who sign Commitment Statements to prevent Sexual and Gender-Based Violence (SGBV) against all students, especially girls = 217 (63 females and 154 males)
1.3.7 # of Community level Decision Makers (Chiefs, Imams, Pastors, PTA Chair persons and Community Health Committee Chair persons, Parents, Youth leaders, women leaders, teachers who take decisions and act in support of gender equality and the prevention of SGBV and discrimination against women. = 471 (130 females and 318 males)
.

description.narrative:
This activity was ot carried out as planned ,due to the fact that implementation started after the election.
However the project through the Affirmative Action Bill Coalition lobby committee was able to engage the Speaker of Parliament and 3 other influential parliamentarians to solicit for their support for the passage of the bill

description.narrative: Number of bye-laws on gender equality, women and girls’ empowerment and ending SGBV enacted and enforced

title.narrative: Out of 33 bye-laws on gender equality, women and girls’ empowerment and ending SGBV were recorded enforced and enacted . 5 of them were already existing law in someof the communities that needed enforced. 29 of them were agreed upon with the community leaders and district assembly representatives(assembly men). They are however above to or in the process of presenting the bye-laws to the district assembly for approval and enactment

description.narrative: Number of bye-laws on gender equality, women and girls’ empowerment and ending SGBV enacted and enforced

The project also decided to employ the use of social and traditional media for as part o their advocacy activities alongside the face to face engagement of the lobby committee

title.narrative: # of platforms where the businesses of the EROP Economic Empowerment Groups are being marketed by journalists and CSOs

description.narrative: Number of platforms where the businesses of the EROP Economic Empowerment Groups are being marketed by journalists and CSOs

title.narrative: 1.2.5. Conduct joint field visits with National Level Stakeholders to the Project areas.

description.narrative: Number of support visits conducted to target communities by national level officers

title.narrative: Number of support visits conducted to target communities by national level officers

description.narrative:
One field visit was conducted by the national level partners ( National Governing Board of GHAlliance, the Penholder(PPAG), Project Management team and A rep from teh Dutch embassy
The team visited Langbinsi - East Mamprusi District,Sirigu- Kassena Nankana West District,Nyangolingo- Kassena Nankana West District,Yarigabisi- Bolgatanga East District,Tamale Metropolitan District and Gbolo Kpalsi- Sagnerigu District

title.narrative: 2.1.1.Mobilize and form women groups or assess existing ones in preparations for training

description.narrative: Number of women groups formed for livelihood and entrepreneurial skills training

title.narrative: # of women groups formed for livelihood and entrepreneurial skills training

description.narrative:
Number of women groups formed for livelihood and entepreneurial skills training
A total of 11 district level EROP Economic Empowerment groups were formed at the district level. This was replicated at community level to form 61 groups with representative of the community group being part of the district level.
a total of 11 district and 61 community EROP Economic Empowerment groups were formed

title.narrative: 1.1.3.Form EROP Support Teams in communities

description.narrative: Number of EROP support teams

title.narrative: # of EROP Support Teams formed and adopted as a strategy to increase knowledge of women, girls, men and boys on gender equality/equity, SGBV and Discrimination against women and girls.

description.narrative: The EROP Support teams were formed at a major strategy for the project at the district level with a representation from each of the five implementing communities. A total of 11 district level EROP Support Teams were formed. During the project implementation, this strategy was replicated at the community level.This led to the formation of Support team in the 55 implementing communities

title.narrative: 1.1.4.Train EROP Support Teams

description.narrative: Number of EROP team members trained

title.narrative: # of EROP Support team members trained to educate, capture and report cases of violence to Social Justice Institutions for full prosecution of perpetrators.

description.narrative: A total of 335 EROP support teams were trained form the 55 implementing communities. This included 185 women and 150 men. The over achievement was due to the fact that in some of the larger communities , more EROP support team members were trained.

title.narrative: # of cases of violence captured and reported by EROP Support Teams to Social Justice Institutions for full prosecution of perpetrators.

description.narrative: These was cases of SGBV reported through the EROP support teams within the communities. The underachievement resulted from the fact that , due to the strong partnerships with the community leaders, some of the minor cases were resolved amicably between the community leaders and the EROP Support team members. This was also because some community members preferred resolving the cases with their community leaders.

title.narrative: 1.2.2.Create referral Networks between beneficiaries and the service point of social justice institutions and amongst the social justice institutions

description.narrative: Number of active referrals made and acted on to address cases of violence reported

title.narrative: # of people reporting cases of violence reported

description.narrative: Number of people reporting cases of violence reported

title.narrative: 1.2.1. Conduct initial meetings with district level social justice institutions e.g DOVVSU, CHRAJ, Social Welfare, Gender Desk Officer, GHS, GES etc for collaboration on increased access to their service

title.narrative: 1.1.2.Produce EROP Educational Materials

description.narrative: Number of educational manuals distributed

title.narrative: # of poster produced and distributed

description.narrative: Various posters on SGBV and Women and Girls empowerment themes were produced and distributed

title.narrative: # of flip charts produced and distributed

description.narrative: Number of flip charts produced and distributed The production of the flipcharts was reprogrammed into support the airing of radio drama within the communities

title.narrative: # of referral coupons produced and distributed

description.narrative: Number of referral coupon produced and distributed The referral coupons were printed for the use of the EROP support teams to refer cases of abuse to the Social Justice Institutions

title.narrative: # of t-shirts produced and distributed

description.narrative: Number of t-shirt produced and distributed T-Shirts were printed to serve as visibility materials for the EROP project within the communities

title.narrative: # of EROP Educational Manual distributed

description.narrative: The educational manuals were distributed to the implementing partners in the districts for the EROP Support team leaders to use in their education with the communities

title.narrative: # of Brochures produced and distributed

description.narrative: The brochures produced and distributed to the implementing partners to share with key stakeholders to educate them on what the EROP project is about

title.narrative: # of leaflets produced and distributed

description.narrative: The leaflets were produced and distributed to implementing partners to use as educational materials in their communities

title.narrative: 1.2.4. Initiate follow ups and back-to-school enrollment and skills development for identified girls and young women who are out of school due to pregnancy/childbirth or any other reasons.

description.narrative: Number of girls reintegrated into schools after dropping-out as a result of teenage pregnancies, early motherhood, child marriage, to continue to pursue their ambitions

title.narrative: 1.1.5. Conduct education for women and girls / men and boys via house-to-house visits and groups engagements in target communities.

description.narrative: Number of women and girls / men and boys via house-to-house visits and groups engagements in target communities.

description.narrative: Number of # of women and girls reached with education on gender equality and SGBV The over-achievement was as a result of the training of more EROP support team members

title.narrative: # of community of members reporting cases of SGBV to EROP Support Teams or Social Justice Institutions for appropriate actions

description.narrative: Number of community members reporting cases. The under-achievement was as a result of some community members preferring to resolve cases internally with the community leadership

1.1.6. Conduct radio programs with call-in, Radio Drama / Theatre, animation videos

description.narrative: Radio programs conducted to create aware of the objective of the EROp project

title.narrative: # of radio, TV programs and community engagement on SGBV conducted by all implementing organisations / CSOs.

description.narrative: Number of radio , TV programs and community engagement on SGB

title.narrative: # of men and boys who act to prevent violence and discrimination against women and girls in their communities.

description.narrative: This indicator captures , men and boys who directly acted to support and prevent violence and discrimination against women and girls in their communities after interacting the EROP project. They included male members of the EROP supports groups and some key community opinion leaders

title.narrative: 1.3.7 Orientation of community leaders (Chiefs, Imams, Pastors, PTA Chair persons and Community Health Committee Chair persons) on EROP Projects

description.narrative: Sensitizing key community stakeholders on the objectives of the EROP project

description.narrative: Step down training conducted for EROP economic empowerment groups

title.narrative: 2.Capacity of women and girls involved in livelihood and entrepreneurial skills to earn income increased in selected districts
% increase in capacity of women and girls involved in livelihood and entrepreneurial skill to earn income

description.narrative:
Increase in capacity of women and girls involved in livelihood and entrepreneurial skill to earn income
At baseline the project recorded 62.8% women and girls involved in livelihood and entrepreneurial skills to earn income.After the implementation , 88.6% was recorded. This indicators a percentage increase 25.8% of women and girls acquiring livelihood and entrepreneurial skill that enable them to earn an income.
